content:
How I Found Myself (And Why It Wasnâ€™t What I Expected) For as long as I can remember, I thought life was supposed to follow a straight line. You pick a dream when youâ€™re youngâ€”astronaut, architect, rockstar, whateverâ€”and then you chase it down, step by step. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™re told, anyway.
But hereâ€™s what nobody tells you: most of us end up somewhere completely different. We blink, years pass, and suddenly weâ€™re not the people we once imagined.
Staring at the Mirror (And Not Recognizing Whoâ€™s There) Iâ€™ve had more than a few moments where I looked in the mirror and thought, â€œWho is this?â€
Not in a dramatic, movie-meltdown kind of wayâ€”just a quiet, subtle sense of not recognizing the version of myself looking back.
Every era of my life feels like it belonged to a different person:
The one who thought heâ€™d be an esports player or a band player. The one who ended up in digital marketing, which was never on my vision board. The one who got back into coding after years away. The cyclist, chasing sunrise rides and sore legs instead ofâ€¦ whatever I thought adulthood was supposed to be. The Unexpected Turns I never set out to be a digital marketer.
I didnâ€™t imagine Iâ€™d be the kind of person who finds joy in analytics dashboards or debugging someoneâ€™s messy code at midnight.
And I definitely never saw myself obsessing over cycling gear, logging kilometers like I was training for the Tour de France.
Sometimes I wonder if Iâ€™m living in someone elseâ€™s bodyâ€”a stranger who just happens to share my name and a few old memories.
Losing and Finding â€œYouâ€ Songs like Bowieâ€™s The Man Who Sold the World or Gotyeâ€™s Somebody That I Used to Know hit me because theyâ€™re about exactly this:
Looking back and seeing a stranger in your own story. Wondering if you â€œsold out,â€ or just grew up. If you lost control, or simply changed.
We all become â€œsomebody I used to knowâ€ at some point, and thatâ€™s okay.
The Truth: Youâ€™re Always Becoming If Iâ€™ve learned anything, itâ€™s this: finding yourself isnâ€™t a destination.
Itâ€™s a constant, messy, beautiful process of becomingâ€”letting go of the old versions and meeting the new ones, over and over.
Some days I miss the person I thought Iâ€™d be.
Most days, though, Iâ€™m grateful for the one Iâ€™ve becomeâ€”even if I had no idea he was coming.
Because in the end, you donâ€™t find yourself all at once.
You find yourself a little bit every day, in every surprise, every detour, every mirror.

title: Call Me

content:
The truth is, Agung was never meant to be my name. My mom wanted Agus â€” you know, the classic Indo name, mass-produced like mie instan ğŸœ. But maybe thatâ€™s the problem. Too many Aguses walking around. So my dad came through with Agung. Sounds like some Bali prince or gamelan prodigyâ€¦ but nope. Just me. Not Balinese. Justâ€¦ here.
Sukariman? Thatâ€™s a whole other drama.
SU from Sulastri, my mom â€” the real MVP.
KARIM, from the Karim family, who literally picked baby me up from the hospital when my parents were broke. No grab, no gojek, just pure kindness â¤ï¸
And MAN? Thatâ€™s for Basman, my dad. Or as I like to call itâ€¦ Bestman. Lols.
So yeah, even my name is a mashup of love, struggle, and last-minute decisions ğŸ²
I was supposed to be in a band ğŸ¸. Or an esports team ğŸ®. Or I dunno, doing something that didnâ€™t involve debugging tracking scripts at 2am. Not to mention that one dream â€” becoming a Game Master at Netmarble. Yup. I really thought I’d be managing MMORPG servers, banning cheaters, and giving away item codes like Oprah. Life said nope.
But here I am â€” writing, clicking, optimizing pixels, and biking long rides ğŸš´â€â™‚ï¸ like Iâ€™m running away from my own roadmap.
Sometimes I look in the mirror and think: am I really living the life I thought I would? Probably not. But at least Iâ€™m still moving. Still me. Just weirder now.
This blog? Donâ€™t expect perfection. Expect detours, noise, unfinished thoughts, and maybe a few dead jokes along the way ğŸ’€
